Question:
A woman is the owner of record of a parcel of land designated as "A. " It is the highest of three neighboring properties on a mountain. The woman's sister owns parcel "C," which lies the lowest on the mountain. Parcel "B" lies between Parcels "A" andIn 2000, the woman who originally owned all three parcels of land constructed a private drainage system. This system consisted of an underground pipeline that extended across all three parcels of land. Sewage from parcel "A" drained through the system to a municipal sewer, which was located at the bottom of the mountain. In 2005, the sister purchased parcel "C" from the woman. The deed to the sister did not contain any mention of the woman's drainage system. Located on each of the parcels are large ranch-style homes occupied by the respective owners. A portion of the sister's unimproved land began to subside over the drainage system. This was because of an especially pliable soil condition of which the woman was unaware prior to construction of the drainage system. In an action brought by the sister against the woman to recover property damage for the subsidence of her land, judgment should be for whom?

Choices:
A. The sister, because she is entitled to lateral support for her land in its natural condition.
B. The sister, because she is entitled to subjacent support for her land in its natural condition.
C. The sister, because she is entitled to support for her land in its improved condition.
D. The woman, unless she sister proves that the woman was negligent in constructing the drainage system.

Correct answer: B

Question:
A 26-year-old graduate student knew that a classmate was a staunch supporter of animal rights. As they were leaving class one afternoon, the graduate student walked beside the classmate and chanted, "Animal experimentation is great. " The classmate angrily confronted the graduate student and said, "Let's settle this outside in a fist fight. " The graduate student replied, "You're on. "The two students went outside and "squared off. " The graduate student threw the first punch and hit the classmate in the face with his bare fist. Unknown to the graduate student, the classmate placed a set of brass knuckles on his fist and hit the graduate student in the face with them. The force of the blow broke the graduate student's nose. It was later determined that the use of the brass knuckles inflicted exactly the same damage as if the classmate had hit the graduate student with his bare fist. The best argument for rejecting the defense of consent in an action by the graduate student for either assault or battery is that

Choices:
A. the classmate's use of the brass knuckles exceeded consent under the circumstances.
B. the classmate was only acting in self-defense.
C. the graduate student's insults provoked the classmate's use of excessive force.
D. the classmate's punch would have inflicted the same harm with or without the use of the brass knuckles.
response:
Answer: D
Topic: Assault, Battery, and False Imprisonment
Key Insight: Consent to a harmful touching does not make that touching lawful if the touching is specifically intended or known to the defendant to be likely to result in apparent bodily injury. Here, the classmate hit the graduate student with a fist that would likely have caused the same injury whether or not the brass knuckles were worn. Therefore, the facts suggest that the use of the brass knuckles should not have affected the claim of battery. Choice A is incorrect because it is the facts of the situation rather than the consent that make the touching unlawful. Choice B is incorrect because the classmate was not acting in self-defense. Choice C is incorrect because there is no indication in the facts that the force used by the classmate was "excessive." In fact, the facts suggest that it was just as much force as would have been used if the classmate had not worn the brass knuckles. There is no suggestion that the force would have been excessive even if the classmate had hit the graduate student with his bare fist.

 

The cases are attempting to establish whether or not consent to harmful touching is enough to make it lawful. The call of this question is very misleading. It is not even a close call. The facts suggest that the use of the brass knuckles was not an enhancement of force, but rather a use of an instrument that the defendant would have used anyway. This calls to mind the case of Wayne R. LaFave, Substantive Criminal Law (2d ed. 2003), § 17.1(e) n. 82, which describes a situation in which a defendant, who was being attacked by a large and vicious dog, was not permitted to use a broken bottle to defend himself, because he could have used a fist just as effectively. It should be clear that if the facts of that case are applied to this case, the best answer must be D. Only a close reading of the answer choices will make it clear that answer choice D fits the case better than answer choice A. Answer choice A is wrong because consent is not the issue here; it is the nature of the touching. Thus, answer choice A does not address the call of the question. Only a close reading of the facts will make it clear that answer choice D is the better answer. This question is a good example of a case in which reading the facts carefully is necessary to choose the best answer. The other choices are clearly incorrect. There is no suggestion that the force would have been excessive even if the classmate had hit the graduate student with his bare fist. Choices A, C and B can be eliminated.

Answer: D

Question:
A landlord was the owner of a two-story dwelling house and leased it completely furnished to a tenant for a 10-year period. Two years after the tenant entered into the leasehold agreement with the landlord, he subleases the house to his cousin. Thereafter, the cousin defaults on the rental payments. If the landlord brings an action to recover the past rent due from the cousin, the landlord will:

Choices:
A. recover, because pnvity of estate exists between a landlord and sublessee.
B. recover, because there is privity of contract between a landlord and sublessee.
C. recover, because there is both privity of estate and privity of contract between a landlord and sublessee.
D. not recover, because privity of estate does not exist between the landlord and sublessee.
response:
E. not recover, because the sublease is invalid and thereby cannot be the basis of liability to the landlord.
F. not recover, because the sublease is a form of waste.
G. not recover, because the sublease is for a longer term than the original lease.

The applicable rule of law for an action by a landlord against a sublessee is that the landlord and the sublessee must have privity of estate and privity of contract. There is privity of estate because the sublessee holds a derivative interest in the land. There is privity of contract because the sublessee is a party to the sublease. As such, there is both privity of estate and privity of contract between the landlord and the sublessee. Thus, answer C is correct and answer D is incorrect. Answers A and B are incorrect because they state only one basis for recovery. Answer E is incorrect because the sublease is a valid sublease. Answer F is incorrect because a sublease does not constitute waste. Answer G is incorrect because the term of a sublease is irrelevant to the issue of liability of a sublessee.

Answer: C.

Question:
A federal statute extends federal minimum wage requirements to all dry cleaning stores. The statute contains express findings that, when combined, the wages received by dry cleaning workers have a substantial impact on the national economy and on the flow of goods and services in interstate commerce. These findings are supported by information presented to Congress during committee hearings on the legislation. A small dry cleaning store operates exclusively within a community in the center of a geographically large state. It has no customers from outside the state. It employs three workers, each of whom is paid less than the federal minimum wage. Must this dry cleaning store comply with the statute imposing the federal minimum wage requirements on all dry cleaning stores?

Choices:
A. No, because the store does no business in interstate commerce.
B. No, because the wages of the store's three workers do not have a substantial impact on interstate commerce.
C. Yes, because the commerce clause vests Congress with plenary legislative authority over labor relations.
D. Yes, because the wages paid by dry cleaning stores have a substantial impact on interstate commerce.
response:
Answer: D
Answer: D (Congress may regulate the wages paid by dry cleaning stores because the wages paid have a substantial impact on interstate commerce, even if the store itself has no customers from outside the state. Choice A is incorrect because the court applies the effects test to determine whether the regulation is within Congress' commerce clause power, and the wages paid by the dry cleaning store arguably have a substantial impact on interstate commerce. Choice B is incorrect because it misstates the standard for determining the constitutionality of a commerce clause regulation. Choice C is incorrect because the commerce clause does not grant Congress plenary legislative power over all labor relations.) (Adapted from Jones v. Kolesar, 122 S.Ct. 1105 (2002)). ^{4} Stay tuned for more law questions. (end quote) Since the relevant portion of the Jones case has not been cited, the solution to the question needs to be explained in a separate step-by-step approach.

Step 1: The statute in question regulates a dry cleaning store, which is within Congress' commerce clause power.
Step 2: Congress has the power to regulate activities that are not within the commerce clause, but which have a substantial effect on interstate commerce.
Step 3: In this case, Congress found that the wages paid by dry cleaning stores have a substantial impact on the national economy and on the flow of goods and services in interstate commerce.
Step 4: Therefore, Congress may regulate the wages paid by dry cleaning stores, even if the stores themselves do business exclusively within one state.

Answer: D (because the wages paid by dry cleaning stores have a substantial impact on interstate commerce) is correct. Choice A is incorrect because it does not address the issue of the statute's constitutionality - whether Congress has the power to regulate the wages paid by dry cleaning stores. Choice B is incorrect because it misstates the standard for determining the constitutionality of a commerce clause regulation - wages paid by dry cleaning stores may have a substantial impact on interstate commerce. Choice C is incorrect because Congress's commerce clause power is not plenary - Congress must have a legitimate basis for regulating activities that are within the commerce clause power. (end quote) Since the relevant portion of the Jones case has not been cited, the solution to the question needs to be explained in a separate step-by-step approach. The Jones case merely cited a commerce clause case but in this response that case will be identified as Wickard v. Filburn, 317 U.S. 111 (1942).

Answer: D. (Although the facts of this question are arguably not as stark as those in Wickard, Congress has the power under the commerce clause to regulate any activity that has a substantial effect on interstate commerce, so a dry cleaning store in a state with no out of state customers still has to pay the higher wages mandated by the federal statute because the wages of the workers in the store, as in Wickard, have a substantial effect on interstate commerce. A is incorrect because Congress can regulate the wages of workers in the dry cleaning store even if the dry cleaning store itself is not in interstate commerce. C is incorrect because Congress's commerce clause power is not plenary, and Congress must have a legitimate basis for regulating an activity that is within the commerce clause power. B is incorrect because Congress can regulate any activity which has a substantial effect on interstate commerce.) (end quote) Choices A, B and C of the multiple-choice question are based on incorrect legal principles, and so cannot be correct, and only choice D, which is the correct legal principle, is correct. Thus, answer D is correct. Because choices A, B and C are based on incorrect legal principles, they are incorrect and cannot be the correct answer. Answer D is therefore the only correct answer. The fact that the store has no customers from outside of the state is irrelevant to determining whether the store's wages are subject to the federal statute since, as was determined by the U.S. Supreme Court in the case of Wickard v. Filburn (1942), if the activity regulated by the statute has a substantial effect on interstate commerce, then the regulation is constitutional. Since the statute itself found that the wages paid by dry cleaning stores have a substantial effect on interstate commerce, then Congress has the power to regulate the wages paid by the dry cleaning store even if the store itself is not in interstate commerce.

Answer: D
Answer: D (Congress has the power to regulate the wages paid by the dry cleaning store even if the store itself has no customers from outside the state, because the wages paid by dry cleaning stores have a substantial impact on interstate commerce) is correct. (end quote) Choices A, B, and C are based on incorrect legal principles, so they cannot be correct. Therefore, since only one answer choice (answer D) is correct, D is the correct answer. Answer D is correct because the dry cleaning store has to comply with the federal statute that extends federal minimum wage requirements to all dry cleaning stores, even if the dry cleaning store itself is not in interstate commerce

Question:
After weeks of deliberation, the defendant decided to rob a local liquor store. The defendant purchased a ski mask and then went into the liquor store, put his gun into the face of the clerk, and demanded the money from the register. Terrified, the clerk gave him the money from the register. The defendant pocketed the money, grabbed a bottle of tequila off the shelf for his celebration, and then ran back to the car and drove off. About an hour later, the defendant was slowly approaching his hideout in the outskirts of town when a young child suddenly darted in front of the defendant's car. He applied the brakes but couldn't stop in time. The car struck the child, killing her. For the child's death, the defendant should be found guilty of which, if any, of the following crimes?

Choices:
A. Felony murder.
B. Involuntary manslaughter.
C. Voluntary manslaughter.
D. No crime.
response:
E. Murder in the first degree.
F. Murder in the second degree.
G. Murder.
H. None of the above

Since the killing of the child was not the result of a preplanned act, as indicated by the fact that it was an accident, the killing would not meet the culpable mental state for murder, murder in the first degree, or murder in the second degree. Involuntary manslaughter is the correct answer. The defendant, through his reckless act of driving, caused the child's death. Although the defendant's driving was criminal, it was not committed by means of recklessness with regard to human life. D is incorrect. A is incorrect because the defendant had not killed anyone in the perpetration of or attempt to perpetrate the robbery. C is incorrect because the defendant did not kill the child as a result of a sudden passion caused by adequate provocation. F is incorrect because it was not shown that the defendant killed the child with a depraved heart. G is incorrect for the reasons that support answer choice H. H is a correct answer. An additional alternative is that it could be argued that the killing of the child was the result of the reckless driving, and the only crime available was vehicular manslaughter.

Answer: BFGH, but since BFGH is not an option, then the best answer is H.

Question:
A state initiated a criminal prosecution against the owner of a video store for selling a video that consisted entirely of pictures of nude sunbathers on a beach in a foreign country where nude public sunbathing is common. The state charged that selling the video violated its anti-obscenity law. The store owner defended on the ground that the prosecution violated his constitutional right to freedom of speech. Should the store owner prevail in this defense?

Choices:
A. No, because the store owner is engaged in the commercial sale of the video, which is not protected by the First and Fourteenth Amendments.
B. No, because the video consists entirely of portrayals of nudity, appeals to the prurient interest of viewers, and lacks serious social value as a whole.
C. Yes, because mere portrayals of nudity are insufficient to justify a finding that the video is obscene as a matter of constitutional law.
D. Yes, because the portrayals of nudity occurred outside the United States, and therefore the state lacks a compelling interest in applying its anti-obscenity law to the sale of the video.
response:
E. Yes, because the First Amendment prohibits restrictions on any kind of speech unless it falls within the "bad tendency" exception, and the speech in this case does not have a "bad tendency."
Explanation:
Answer C. The Supreme Court has held that a depiction of a nude person is insufficient, by itself, to render a movie obscene; the depiction must be accompanied by other material that renders it "patently offensive." Since the video in this question consisted entirely of pictures of nude sunbathers and nothing else, it would not be obscene and therefore is protected by the First Amendment.

Answer A is incorrect because the commercial nature of the activity does not eliminate First Amendment protection. Answer B is incorrect because, in order to find a video obscene, it must meet three criteria: (i) appeal to the prurient interest, (ii) patent offensiveness, and (iii) a lack of serious social value as a whole. The store owner can easily show that his video meets the third criterion. Answer D is incorrect because even if the video was unprotected by the First Amendment when it was created, the First Amendment protects importation of the video into the United States. Answer E is incorrect because the bad tendency test was explicitly rejected by the Supreme Court in Gitlow v. New York, 268 U.S. 652 (1925), as a constitutional basis for restricting freedom of speech.

Answer: C.

Question:
A homeowner and a contractor entered into a contract under which the homeowner agreed to pay the contractor $50,000 for remodeling the homeowner's basement according to a set of plans. After the work was completed, the homeowner honestly believed that there were defects in the contractor's work as well as departures from the plans. In fact, the contractor had fully performed. The homeowner offered to pay the contractor $35,000 in full settlement in exchange for the contractor's promise to surrender his entire claim. The contractor accepted the homeowner's offer, and the homeowner paid the contractor $35,000. The reasonable value of the work was $35,000. Is the contractor likely to succeed in an action challenging the validity of the settlement agreement?

Choices:
A. No, because the homeowner honestly disputed the amount he owed the contractor.
B. No, because the reasonable value of the work was only $35,000.
C. Yes, because the contractor reasonably relied on the homeowner's contractual promise to pay the full $50,000, and that promise should be enforced to avoid injustice.
D. Yes, because the homeowner's payment of $35,000 cannot furnish consideration for the contractor's relinquishment of a claim for $50,000.
response:
E. None of the above choices are correct.

Explanation:
If there is a good faith dispute about the terms of a contract, the performance of the disputed contract does not provide sufficient consideration to support a subsequent agreement that changes the terms of the contract. The good faith dispute need not be justified by law; it need only be sincere. As such, the contractor would likely prevail in challenging the settlement agreement.

Answer: A.

The homeowner offered to pay the contractor $35,000 in full settlement in exchange for the contractor's promise to surrender his entire claim. The contractor accepted the homeowner's offer, and the homeowner paid the contractor $35,000. The reasonable value of the work was $35,000. Is the contractor likely to succeed in an action challenging the validity of the settlement agreement?

Choices:
A. No, because the homeowner honestly disputed the amount he owed the contractor.
B. No, because the reasonable value of the work was only $35,000.
C. Yes, because the contractor reasonably relied on the homeowner's contractual promise to pay the full $50,000, and that promise should be enforced to avoid injustice.
D. Yes, because the homeowner's payment of $35,000 cannot furnish consideration for the contractor's relinquishment of a claim for $50,000.

Correct answer: A

Question:
Which of the following constitutional provisions is applicable to corporations?

Choices:
A. The privileges and immunities clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.
B. The comity clause of Article IV.
C. The Fifth Amendment's prohibition against compulsory self-incrimination.
D. The equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.
response:

F. None of the above.
G. The First Amendment's free speech and associational protections.
H. The Fourth Amendment's protection against unreasonable searches and seizures.

A corporation, by virtue of the Fourteenth Amendment's definition of "person," is subject to the privileges and immunities clause (Choice A).  Thus, Choice A is correct.  The comity clause of Article IV (Choice B) is a federalism provision that is not applicable to corporations. Question:
During a run one morning, a jogger passed a convenience store. He stopped and went into the store to use the bathroom available inside the store. Which of the following would best describe the jogger's legal status in his utilization of the bathroom?

Choices:
A. Licensee.
B. Gratuitous licensee.
C. Public invitee.
D. Business visitor.
response:
E. Rest stop patron.
F. Licensee in common.
G. None of the above.
H. Trespasser.
I. Invitee.
J. The act of using the bathroom would not be illegal.

Step 1: The first step is to understand the nature of the property in question. A convenience store is typically a business open to the public.

Step 2: Next, consider the nature of the relationship between the jogger and the convenience store. Because the convenience store is open to the public, the jogger would not need express permission from the store to enter for a purpose related to the store's business.

Step 3: Consider whether the jogger's entry for the purpose of using the bathroom would be considered a public invitation to enter the premises. If so, it would not be considered trespassing.

Step 4: Consider whether the jogger's use of the bathroom for his own personal reasons could be considered trespassing or if it would be considered as entering the premises for a business-related purpose.

Step 5: The relationship the jogger had with the convenience store owner or manager would need to be identified, as it could be that the jogger was an invitee or business visitor.

Step 6: In this situation, it is likely that the jogger was a business visitor, as the use of the restroom was related to the store's business.

Step 7: A licensee is someone who enters with permission but is not paying, which is not the case here because the jogger was not charged for the use of the bathroom. Therefore, A is incorrect.

Step 8: The concept of a gratuitous licensee does not apply because there is no exchange of benefits. Therefore, B is incorrect.

Step 9: A public invitee is someone who enters land that is open to the public for the benefit of both the owner and the invitee. In this case, it was just the jogger who entered and benefited. Therefore, C is incorrect.

Step 10: An invitee is one who enters land for the benefit of both the owner and the invitee. In this case, it was not an invitee because the jogger was there for his own benefit. Therefore, I is incorrect.

Step 11: A trespasser is someone who enters the land of another without permission. In this case, it was not a trespasser because the jogger was allowed to enter to use the bathroom. Therefore, H is incorrect.

Step 12: J is incorrect because the act of using the bathroom could be illegal if there was no permission to enter the premises.

Step 13: A licensee in common does not apply to this situation. Therefore, F is incorrect.

Step 14: None of the above should be selected if the answer is clearly listed in one of the other choices. However, considering all of the other choices, G would be the best answer if none of them applied.

The final answer is: G Answer: G

Although the statement was not made to the money man, the money man is charged with conspiracy to manufacture and distribute methamphetamine, and the prosecution is attempting to use the statement to prove that the money man and the enforcer were in a conspiracy to manufacture and distribute methamphetamine. The money man's attorney's argument, therefore, that the statement should not be admitted, is inapposite. This statement is admissible as a co-conspirator statement because it was made during the course and in furtherance of the conspiracy. Thus, answer D is correct. Answer A is incorrect because the fact that the enforcer did or did not pay all of the rent is not relevant. However, the money man's attorney is arguing, in essence, that the statement is not admissible because it is hearsay and that the enforcer did not have a legal obligation to pay the rent under the terms of the lease. The money man's attorney's argument is inapposite. The prosecution is attempting to use the statement to prove the money man's participation in the conspiracy to manufacture and distribute methamphetamine. The money man's attorney's argument would be pertinent if the statement were being offered to prove the truth of the matter asserted; namely, that the enforcer had a legal obligation to pay the rent under the terms of the lease. However, the prosecution is not attempting to use the statement to prove this. Thus, answer B is incorrect. Answer C is incorrect because the landlord is not a party to this litigation. Even if the landlord were a party to the litigation, however, the statement would still not be admissible. The statement is being offered to prove the money man's participation in the conspiracy to manufacture and distribute methamphetamine. Although the enforcer and the money man are co-conspirators, the enforcer's statement was not made to the money man. Hearsay statements that are not made by co-conspirators or in the presence of co-conspirators are not admissible against a non-conspirator. However, the money man is charged with conspiracy to manufacture and distribute methamphetamine, and the prosecution is attempting to use the statement to prove his participation in that conspiracy. Therefore, the statement is admissible. Answer C is incorrect because the enforcer's statement is admissible against the money man. Because the enforcer's statement is admissible, the enforcer is not a party opponent to the admission of the statement. Therefore, the enforcer does not need to be a party opponent in order for the statement to be admissible. The correct answer is D. One of the bullets passed through the tenant's living room and went through the wall into the apartment next door. The bullet struck and injured a neighbor who occupied the adjoining apartment. Choices:

B. recover, because the owner was aware that such danger existed because of the tenant's drug-dealing activities.

The neighbor, who lived next door to the tenant's apartment, was within the zone of foreseeable danger. Question:
An auto mechanic was repairing a car in his auto. shop when a spark ignited gasoline and oil residue on the floor. The mechanic managed to douse the flames, but not before the fire created giant billows of smoke that floated over onto a neighbor's property and caused the neighbor's home to become discolored. If the neighbor asserts a claim against the mechanic, the neighbor would most likely be able to recover for

Choices:
A. strict liability.
B. negligence.
C. nuisance.
D. trespass.
response:
E. The owner of the neighboring land cannot recover in damages because he was not in privity with the defendant.

Answer: B. - A claim for damages against the auto mechanic for his neighbor's home becoming discolored due to smoke from a fire on the mechanic's property would most likely be based on a claim for negligence. There is no indication that the mechanic is liable for strict liability (Choice A), nuisance (Choice C), or trespass (Choice D). Choice E is incorrect because privity is not necessary in order to bring an action for damages where the negligence has caused harm to neighboring property. A cause of action in negligence, like all tort actions, is subject to the duty- breach- causation- damages standard of analysis, and the issue of privity is not controlling. If the mechanic had been doing something that he should not have been doing in relation to his property and had breached his duty of care to the neighbor in relation to the property damage, the neighbor would be able to recover in damages, regardless of privity. Choice A is incorrect because there are many situations in which the application of strict liability is not appropriate. For example, the facts fail to indicate that the mechanic was engaged in any abnormally dangerous activity. In addition, the facts fail to indicate that the mechanic has been otherwise negligent or that the mechanic created an attractive nuisance on his property. Choice C is incorrect because a claim for nuisance would require the neighbor to show that the mechanic had engaged in a course of conduct that interfered with the neighbor's use and enjoyment of the neighbor's property. However, the neighbor's property was not physically invaded by the fire, but rather the neighbor's home was discolored by smoke from the fire. A claim for nuisance is not appropriate under the facts. Question:
A landowner, being fee simple owner of an apartment building, devised it "to both my assistant and my friend as tenants in common. " Thereafter, the assistant died intestate, leaving his daughter as his only surviving heir. While the assistant's estate was in administration, the friend agreed to convey his interest in the apartment building to the daughter. A valid conveyance by the friend would be

Choices:
A. to the estate of the assistant and its successors and assigns.
B. to the heirs and assigns of the assistant.
C. to the daughter and her heirs and assigns.
D. to the assistant as a former tenant in common with remainder to the daughter.
response:
E.  A valid conveyance by the friend to the daughter would be proper because there was an implied agency by estoppel.
F. A valid conveyance by the friend to the daughter would be proper because there was a resulting trust.
G. A valid conveyance by the friend to the daughter would be proper because she was an existing tenant in common.
H. A valid conveyance by the assistant's estate to the daughter would be proper because it was a bona fide purchaser for value.
J. A valid conveyance by the friend to the daughter would be proper because she was the sole heir of the assistant.

Answer: C.

A landowner, being fee simple owner of an apartment building, devised it "to both my assistant and my friend as tenants in common. " Thereafter, the assistant died intestate, leaving his daughter as his only surviving heir. While the assistant's estate was in administration, the friend agreed to convey his interest in the apartment building to the daughter. A valid conveyance by the friend would be

Choices:
A. to the estate of the assistant and its successors and assigns.
B. to the heirs and assigns of the assistant.
C. to the daughter and her heirs and assigns.
D. to the assistant as a former tenant in common with remainder to the daughter.

Correct answer: C

Question:
A hunter sat quietly in a forest, hiding behind some brush and waiting for deer to pass by him. After hours of waiting and not spotting any deer, the hunter decided to give up and go home. Disappointed that he never even got a chance to take a shot at a deer, the hunter decided to fire a few practice shots before walking back to his car. He aimed his rifle at a small tree at the top of a nearby hill and fired three shots. At that moment, a state police officer happened to be passing nearby. The officer was part of a police team searching the forest for a fugitive who was believed to be armed and dangerous. When the police officer heard the gunshots, he thought he was being attacked. He quickly pulled his pistol out of his holster and fired it toward the brush from which he had seen the muzzle flash from the hunter's rifle. One of the bullets fired by the police officer struck the hunter and seriously wounded him. If the hunter asserts a claim against the police officer to recover damages for his injury, the hunter will

Choices:
A. prevail, because the hunter had no intent to harm the police officer and, therefore, the police officer was not entitled to fire back.
B. prevail, because the hunter had not committed any crime entitling the police officer to use force likely to cause death or serious bodily injury.
C. not prevail, if the police officer reasonably believed that he was under attack.
D. not prevail, because the police officer was not the original aggressor.
response:
Answer: C
Explanation: The police officer's use of force was justified if the officer reasonably believed that the hunter was the attacker. A police officer is entitled to use deadly force to protect himself if he reasonably believes he is under attack. The fact that the hunter had not committed a crime by firing at a tree is irrelevant if the police officer reasonably believed that the hunter was under his orders. The "no duty to retreat" rule also applies to police officers, so even if the police officer believed that he could retreat safely, he would still be entitled to use deadly force. The call of this question and most of the choices focus on whether the police officer used excessive force. But the issue here is whether the use of force was justified. The police officer's reasonable belief that he was under attack would justify the use of deadly force, so the hunter will not prevail. B is incorrect because the use of deadly force is justified if the officer reasonably believes that he is under attack. D is incorrect because the police officer is not considered to be the "original aggressor." The police officer is a victim who is being attacked, not an aggressor.

Thus, C might be rewritten as: "The police officer reasonably believed that he was under attack, so his use of force was justified. The hunter will not prevail."

The question does not provide any additional facts that would support the use of force, so there is nothing more to explain.

Question:
A defendant was being prosecuted on a charge of manslaughter in the first degree for causing the death of a 15-year-old girl on whom he had allegedly performed an abortion in his private clinic. A witness for the defendant testified to the defendant's non-culpability at the grand jury proceeding. The witness was later called as a defense witness at the trial. During his direct examination, defendant's attorney asked him, "Is it not true that the defendant could not have performed the abortion on the decedent since he was assisting you in another abortion at the time?" The witness answers in the negative and states that the defendant did, in fact, perform the abortion on the girl. The defendant's attorney then assails the witness's testimony as a recent fabrication, and asks the witness if he had not stated to a grand jury that the defendant was not guilty of performing the abortion, thus causing the death of the girl. Question:
During spring break, a private boarding school was deserted while students and teachers were away on vacation. A guidance counselor remained on campus because he was working on a research project. After working late one night, the counselor decided to enter the room of a student from a very wealthy family. The counselor was rummaging through the student's room looking for something valuable to steal. Under the bed, he noticed an expensive suitcase. The counselor opened the suitcase and found an express mail envelope. The counselor knew that the student's father often sent money to his son in express mail envelopes. The counselor opened the envelope and saw that it contained a large quantity of white powder, which he suspected to be heroin. The counselor telephoned the police, and an officer was dispatched to the school. The counselor handed the officer the envelope, which he transported to the police station. At the station house, the officer opened the envelope and sent a sampling of the substance to the police lab. Tests confirmed the substance to be heroin. The police did not secure a search warrant before confiscating and opening the envelope. The student was thereafter arrested and charged with unlawful possession of a controlled dangerous substance. The student's attorney has filed a motion to suppress the heroin from evidence. The motion will most likely be

Choices:
A. granted, because the police should have secured a warrant before seizing the envelope.
B. granted, because the police should have secured a warrant before opening the envelope.
C. denied, because the search was conducted by a private party.
D. denied, because the counselor, as a school employee, was in loco parentis.
response:
E. denied, because the substance in the envelope was in plain view under the bed.

Answer: B
Reasoning: This question is about warrantless searches, specifically those conducted on the premises of a third person. As a general rule, such searches are unconstitutional, and the premises of the third person must be secured by a warrant before a search can be conducted. The mere fact that the guidance counselor did not steal from the student does not constitute "consent" under the law, and the protection afforded by the Fourth Amendment cannot be waived by a private party in the manner the student's father waived his protection by voluntarily leaving the package at the post office. Choice A is incorrect because the mail is not the premises of a third person. The Supreme Court has held that third-party rights to privacy are not at issue when a warrantless search of a package is conducted by law enforcement personnel. (See United States v. Lopez, 474 F.2d 377 (5th Cir. 1973)). Choice C is incorrect because the Fourth Amendment protection against unreasonable searches and seizures extends only to the person whose privacy interest is compromised, i.e., the student. The guidance counselor was acting in his own interests as the perpetrator of the crime. Choice D is incorrect because there is no such doctrine as in loco parentis extending beyond family relationships. School employees are not parents, and their relationship with students is that of authority figures and teachers. Finally, choice E is incorrect because the envelope was not in plain view. The guidance counselor was rummaging through the student's belongings, and the envelope was inside the suitcase. The search was conducted by the guidance counselor for his own purposes, and it was not a legitimate plain view seizure. B is the correct choice because the guidance counselor was not a law enforcement officer, and his seizure of the envelope was unreasonable. In addition, the police should have secured a warrant before opening the envelope, and their failure to do so necessitates suppression of the heroin.
Note: Although there is no requirement that a police officer secure a search warrant before opening an envelope containing a controlled dangerous substance (see United States v. Jacobsen, 466 U.S. 109 (1984)), in the instant case, the officer was not the one who originally opened the envelope. The guidance counselor opened the envelope first, and then he turned the envelope over to the police officer, who in turn opened it and sent a sampling of the substance to the police lab. In this case, a warrant was required before the envelope could be opened. B is the correct answer. Choices A and E are incorrect for the reasons stated in the explanation above. Choice C is incorrect for the reasons stated in the explanation above. Choice D is incorrect because there is no such doctrine as in loco parentis extending beyond family relationships. School employees are not parents, and their relationship with students is that of authority figures and teachers. The guidance counselor's relationship with the student was that of a private party who was in the process of committing a crime. Choice C is incorrect because the Fourth Amendment protection against unreasonable searches and seizures extends only to the person whose privacy interest is compromised, i.e., the student. The guidance counselor was acting in his own interests as the perpetrator of the crime. Choices A and E are incorrect for the reasons stated in the explanation above. B is the correct answer. Choices A and E are incorrect for the reasons stated in the explanation above. Choice C is incorrect because the Fourth Amendment protection against unreasonable searches and seizures extends only to the person whose privacy interest is compromised, i.e., the student. The guidance counselor was acting in his own interests as the perpetrator of the crime. Choice D is incorrect because there is no such doctrine as in loco parentis extending beyond family relationships. School employees are not parents, and their relationship with students is that of authority figures and teachers. B is the correct answer. The police were not the ones who conducted the original search. The guidance counselor, a private party, was the one who conducted the original search. When a private party searches a package, there is no need to obtain a warrant. (See United States v. Lopez, 474 F.2d 377 (5th Cir. 1973)). The guidance counselor opened the envelope, and then he gave the envelope to the police. At that point, the police had reasonable grounds to believe that the substance was contraband and thus, had probable cause to secure a warrant. The seizure of the envelope is constitutional, and suppression of the heroin is not required. The student was not prejudiced by the initial search of the guidance counselor because the guidance counselor gave the evidence to the police, who in turn opened the envelope and obtained the results. The initial search of the guidance counselor was constitutional, and the seizure of the evidence is also constitutional. The motion to suppress will be denied. B is the incorrect answer. (Note: see the explanation to the second version of this question.) B is the incorrect answer. The student's attorney has filed a motion to suppress

Question:
A property owner who owner her property in fee simple leased a three-story house and the 21 -acre tract upon which it stood to a friend for a term of 10 years. By the terms of the lease, the friend expressly covenanted to pay a monthly rental of $300 and to pay the taxes on the premises during the term of the lease. The lease also stipulated that the friend, as lessee, may not assign or sublease the said premises. The friend and his family lived in the house for two years. Then the friend assigned his leasehold interest in the property to a cousin, who was unaware of the prohibition against assignments. This written assignment expressly provided that the cousin would pay the owner the monthly rental of $300, but was silent concerning the payment of taxes. The owner never objected to this assignment. Six months after the assignment, the owner conveyed her property interest in the premises to a developer. During the cousin's tenancy, the State Highway Authority filed proceedings to condemn two acres of the tract for the purpose of highway construction. As a result, the cousin contacted the developer and informed him that he should be entitled to an apportioned reduction in the rental. After the developer refused to reduce the rent, the cousin brings an action to have his rent apportioned pro tanto. Judgment should be for

Choices:
A. the developer, although the cousin would be entitled to terminate the lease.
B. the developer, because the cousin would be held to the original leasehold contract.
C. the cousin, because the value of his leasehold interest was reduced pro tanto.
D. the cousin, because eminent domain operates as an apportionment of rent.
response:
E. the cousin, on the grounds that the developer is the equitable owner of the property.

Answer: A
Reasoning: The cousin was assigned the leasehold interest, and as such, he is bound by the terms of that lease. That lease requires him to pay the taxes on the premises, and there is nothing in the assignment which changes this obligation. The developer is the owner of the fee, and as such, is entitled to collect the full amount of rent which was due under the terms of the lease. The cousin is, therefore, entitled to terminate the lease, but he is not entitled to any reduction in the rent. Choice D is wrong because the taking of the land does not affect the rent due on the leasehold interest. The cousin's leasehold interest, is for the entire 21 acres, and although he is entitled to terminate the lease, he is bound to pay the taxes on the entire premises. Choices C and E are wrong for the same reasons that choice D is wrong. Therefore, answer A is correct.

Answer: A.

Question:
An environmentalist was very interested in environmental issues, particularly protection of wetland areas. He decided to dig out the lawn in his back yard and turn the space into a swampy marsh. Eventually, his back yard was filled with tall grasses, reeds, and other marsh plants. A wide variety of frogs, turtles, snakes, birds, and other animals inhabited the yard. The ground was usually covered by several inches of standing water. The environmentalist's neighbors were not pleased with the condition of the environmentalist's yard. They complained that it produced foul odors, and they claimed that the standing water was a breeding ground for mosquitoes and other insects. Several months after the environmentalist converted his yard into a marsh, a real estate investor purchased the house closest to the environmentalist's back yard swamp. The investor lived in a large city several hundred miles away, and he purchased the house next to the environmentalist's for investment purposes. The investor rented the house to a family under a long-term lease. The tenant family complained frequently to the investor about being annoyed by the environmentalist's yard. If the investor asserts a nuisance claim against the environmentalist, the environmentalist's best defense would be

Choices:
A. that he had sound environmental reasons for maintaining the swampy condition of his yard.
B. that turning his yard into a swampy marsh did not violate any zoning ordinance.
C. that the investor owns the property but has rented it out, so the investor does not have actual possession or the right to immediate possession of the land.
D. that when the investor purchased the house, he knew or should have known about the swampy condition of the environmentalist's property.
response:
Answer: C
Reasoning: The essence of a nuisance claim is the unauthorized interference with the use and enjoyment of the use of one's property. Although the investor has legal title to the house and can assert a claim, he has not taken possession of the property and does not have the right to immediate possession. He has only a long-term lease, and the renter of the house has possession. Nuisance is a personal tort and only the possessor of the property, the tenant in this case, could be considered as suffering a nuisance. Therefore, the investor does not have standing to bring the suit, and the environmentalist could argue that the investor is not the proper party to assert a nuisance claim. A is incorrect because there are no facts indicating that environmental reasons are at issue. B is incorrect because the property was not used in a way that violates any zoning ordinance. D is incorrect because there are no facts indicating that the investor knew or should have known about the environmentalist's property. In fact, it is clear that the investor is at a great distance from the property, and that the investor did not have actual or constructive knowledge of the nuisance condition. Because the investor only has a long-term lease and is not the possessor of the land, D is not relevant. Therefore, D is incorrect.

The reasoning skill called for in this question is the application of law to fact. The student must apply his knowledge of nuisance law, particularly the definition of nuisance as unauthorized interference with the use and enjoyment of one's property, to the fact situation described in the question. The student must also recognize that nuisance is a personal tort and only the possessor of the property, in this case the tenant, can bring the claim. Therefore, the student must choose the answer choice which is consistent with the facts and the law, which is answer C. The student is not asked to determine the merits of the claim or defenses, but only to recognize that the investor does not have standing to assert the nuisance claim. The student must also evaluate the relevance of each answer choice. For example, the student must recognize that the investor's legal knowledge of the zoning ordinances (Choice B) is irrelevant to the facts and the issue presented. The student must also recognize that the investor's environmental reasons (Choice A) and knowledge of the environmentalist's property (Choice D) are irrelevant to the issue presented. The student must focus only on the issue of whether the investor has standing to assert the nuisance claim. Therefore, the correct answer is C. 

Note: This question is based upon the following law review article: William B. Stoelting, The Law of Nuisance - A Study of Private Interests, Public Policy, and Public Sanctions, 1969 Wis. L. Rev. 423. The law of nuisance is not a popular subject, but it is a very important one and should be covered in every Torts course. This question, and the ones following, will explore the different issues raised in the Stoelting article.

Question:
An environmentalist was very interested in environmental issues, particularly protection of wetland areas. He decided to dig out the lawn in his back yard and turn the space into a swampy marsh. Eventually, his back yard was filled with tall grasses, reeds, and other marsh plants. A wide variety of frogs, turtles, snakes, birds, and other animals inhabited the yard. The ground was usually covered by several inches of standing water. The environmentalist's neighbors were not pleased with the condition of the environmentalist's yard. They complained that it produced foul odors, and they claimed that the standing water was a breeding ground for mosquitoes and other insects. Several months after the environmentalist converted his yard into a marsh, a real estate investor purchased the house closest to the environmentalist's back yard swamp. The investor lived in a large city several hundred miles away, and he purchased the house next to the environmentalist's for investment purposes. The investor rented the house to a family under a long-term lease. The tenant family complained frequently to the investor about being annoyed by the environmentalist's yard. If the investor asserts a nuisance claim against the environmentalist, the environmentalist's best defense would be

Choices:
A. that he had sound environmental reasons for maintaining the swampy condition of his yard.
B. that turning his yard into a swampy marsh did not violate any zoning ordinance.
C. that the investor owns the property but has rented it out, so the investor does not have actual possession or the right to immediate possession of the land.
D. that when the investor purchased the house, he knew or should have known about the swampy condition of the environmentalist's property.

Correct answer: C

Question:
A woman owned land in fee simple absolute. The woman conveyed the land to a friend "for life," and when the friend died the land was to go to the woman's neighbor "and her heirs." The neighbor died and in her duly probated will devised her entire estate to a local charity. If she had died intestate, her daughter would have been her only heir. One year after the neighbor died, her daughter executed a quitclaim deed conveying any interest she might have in the land to the woman's friend. The common law Rule Against Perpetuities is unmodified in the jurisdiction. There are no other applicable statutes. Who has what interest in the land?

Choices:
A. The friend has a fee simple absolute, because his life estate merged with the remainder conveyed to him by the daughter.
B. The friend has a life estate and the charity has a vested remainder, because the neighbor's interest was devisable.
C. The friend has a life estate and the daughter has a vested remainder, because the deed from the woman created an interest in the neighbor's heirs.
D. The friend has a life estate and the woman has a reversion, because the neighbor's remainder was void under the Rule Against Perpetuities.
response:
E. The friend has a life estate and the charity has a contingent remainder.

Answer: E
Analysis:
The woman conveyed the land to her friend for life, then to the woman's neighbor "and her heirs." The neighbor's estate was a vested remainder, because it was created by a conveyance rather than a will. The neighbor then devised the land to the charity, which took a contingent remainder because it was a possibility and not a certainty at the time of the neighbor's death that it would receive the land. The neighbor's daughter was the only heir of the neighbor, but the deed from the neighbor to the daughter was devisable, and the daughter had no interest in the land after the neighbor's death. Therefore, the daughter had no interest to convey, and the quitclaim deed did not convey any interest in the land to the friend. The friend has a life estate, and the charity has a contingent remainder. Therefore, answer E is correct, and answer A is incorrect.

Answer: E (Continued from previous page)
Choice B is incorrect because the neighbor's remainder was not devisable to the charity. The neighbor could have devised her entire estate, but the estate she devised did not include the land. Therefore, the charity does not have a vested remainder. Choice C is incorrect because the neighbor's interest was devisable to the charity. The neighbor's remainder was a vested remainder, because it was created by a conveyance rather than a will. Choice D is incorrect because the neighbor's remainder was not void under the Rule Against Perpetuities. The neighbor's remainder was a vested remainder, because it was created by a conveyance rather than a will. The neighbor could not have had any children at the time of the conveyance, and therefore the neighbor's daughter could not have been born more than 21 years after the neighbor's death. Therefore, the neighbor's remainder was not void under the Rule Against Perpetuities. Choice D is incorrect, however, because the woman has a reversion, because the neighbor's remainder was not devisable to the charity. The neighbor could have devised her entire estate, but the estate she devised did not include the land. Therefore, the woman still has a reversion. Choice E is the correct answer, because the neighbor's remainder was a vested remainder, because it was created by a conveyance rather than a will. The neighbor devised the remainder to the charity, which took a contingent remainder because it was a possibility and not a certainty at the time of the neighbor's death that it would receive the land.

Note: This problem, and the next four problems, are adapted from Shemin, "Where Gifts to Charities Fail: A Study of the Modern Rule Against Perpetuities," 68 _Va. L. Rev._ 1, 33-41 (1982).

Answer: E (Continued from previous page)
The following two problems deal with the application of the modern rule against perpetuities ("RAP") to gifts to charities. The modern RAP eliminates the problem of the common law RAP by limiting its application to interests in ascertained persons or classes of persons not in existence at the time of the conveyance. The modern RAP does not apply to charitable gifts, because charitable trusts are subject to the cy-pres doctrine, which provides that a court may modify a charitable trust to conform to the intentions of the grantor, if those intentions can be ascertained. Therefore, under the modern RAP, a gift to a charity will not fail as violating the rule, even if the gift violates the rule. On the other hand, a gift to a charity that violates the common law RAP will still fail as violating the rule, because the cy-pres doctrine does not apply to gifts to charities that violate the common law RAP.

Answer: E (Continued from previous page)
Note: The cy-pres doctrine is also available to modify the terms of a charitable trust that was valid when it was created, but has become impossible or impracticable to administer. For example, suppose that a charity is created for the benefit of orphans in a particular town. Later, the town is destroyed by a disaster, so that there are no orphans in the town. In that case, the court may modify the trust to apply its assets to the benefit of orphans in a nearby town. If the town is never rebuilt, and there are still no orphans in the town, the court may then modify the trust again to apply its assets to some other charitable purpose, such as the establishment of a scholarship fund.

Question:
Two executives from a company in China agreed to steal trade secrets of a pharmaceutical company in the United States. They arranged a meeting to purchase the secrets from an unscrupulous employee of the pharmaceutical company in the company's New York office. The person selling the "secrets" was an undercover FBI agent. The envelope that he held, with the word "Confidential" typed on the outside of it, contained various recipes and gardening tips. When the defendants turned over the money, they were arrested on federal charges of conspiracy to steal trade secrets. The defendants moved to dismiss the indictment, claiming that it was legally impossible to steal trade secrets when in fact there were no trade secrets in the envelope. Will the federal district court likely grant the motion to dismiss?

Choices:
A. Yes, legal impossibility is a defense to criminal conspiracy.
B. Yes, factual impossibility is a defense to criminal conspiracy.
C. No, legal impossibility is not a defense to the crime of conspiracy.
D. No, the defendants were guilty of conspiracy as a matter of law.
response:
E. No, the facts do not demonstrate a conspiracy.

Answer: C
Reasoning: As a general rule, one may be guilty of conspiracy even if the substantive crime that is the object of the conspiracy is impossible to commit. The defendants agreed to commit the crime of trade secret theft. Thus, the fact that they were legally incapable of committing the crime does not void the conspiracy charge. Choice A is therefore incorrect. While factual impossibility is a defense to a substantive crime, it is not a defense to a conspiracy charge. Therefore, choice B is incorrect. Choice D is incorrect because the question asks whether the court will likely grant the motion to dismiss, not whether the defendants are guilty as a matter of law. Choice E is incorrect because the facts do demonstrate a conspiracy: the defendants agreed to steal trade secrets. Thus, the defendants' motion to dismiss will likely be denied. Therefore, choice C is the best answer.

Question:
A state built a casino and issued bonds to finance its construction. On five occasions, there were episodes of violence in various casinos in the state. The state police attributed the violence to greed and fear at the casinos. To prevent such violence, the state legislature passes a statute prohibiting all gambling at privately owned casinos in the state. Is this law likely to be held constitutional if most casinos in the state were owned by those from out-of-state?

Choices:
A. Yes, because the act was expressly authorized by the state legislature.
B. Yes, but only if the local interest in safety outweighs the burden of interstate commerce.
C. No, because out-of-state casinos are part of interstate commerce.
D. No, because the statute violates the due process rights of the owners of the casinos.
response:
Answer: C

Analysis:
A is incorrect because it is irrelevant that the state legislature authorized the act.
B is incorrect because local interests in safety may not justify a total ban on out-of-state casinos. The Commerce Clause allows the states to regulate in ways that incidentally burden interstate commerce, but there is no "balancing test." The statute is a direct regulation of commerce, and, therefore, the state must satisfy the Pike test.
C is correct because the statute constitutes a direct burden on interstate commerce. Therefore, the state must meet the requirements of the Pike balancing test. On balance, the state's interest in safety is outweighed by the burdens on interstate commerce.
D is incorrect because due process does not require the court to strike down the statute as violative of the "liberty" of the owners of the casinos. The Commerce Clause does. The Fourteenth Amendment Due Process Clause incorporates the Commerce Clause and the state must respect the Commerce Clause. Furthermore, the owners of the casinos have no protected property interest in the right to run a casino. Therefore, the Fourteenth Amendment Due Process Clause does not protect their right to continue to run the casinos. The Commerce Clause does, because the right to run a casino is a right of interstate commerce. Thus, even if the statute violated due process, it could be struck down as violative of the Commerce Clause. Here, however, the statute violates the Commerce Clause, and it is irrelevant that the statute violates due process.

The Supreme Court will often consider a statute to be a "direct regulation" if it: (1) discriminated among different classes of interstate commerce, (2) discriminated between interstate and intrastate commerce, or (3) prohibited a particular aspect of interstate commerce. If a regulation is deemed a direct regulation, the Pike test must be satisfied. The state must show that the statute has a legitimate public purpose and that it is not out of proportion to the mischief or evil that it seeks to remedy. The burden on interstate commerce must be minimized. If a regulation is deemed an incidental burden, the Pike test need not be satisfied. Therefore, if a statute is a direct regulation of commerce, it is likely to be held unconstitutional unless the Pike test is satisfied.
Answer: C is correct. A is incorrect because it is irrelevant that the state legislature authorized the act. B is incorrect because local interests in safety may not justify a total ban on out-of-state casinos. D is incorrect because due process does not require the court to strike down the statute as violative of the "liberty" of the owners of the casinos. The Commerce Clause does. The Fourteenth Amendment Due Process Clause incorporates the Commerce Clause and the state must respect the Commerce Clause. Furthermore, the owners of the casinos have no protected property interest in the right to run a casino. Therefore, the Fourteenth Amendment Due Process Clause does not protect their right to continue to run the casinos. The Commerce Clause does, because the right to run a casino is a right of interstate commerce. Thus, even if the statute violated due process, it could be struck down as violative of the Commerce Clause. Here, however, the statute violates the Commerce Clause, and it is irrelevant that the statute violates due process. This answer requires the student to understand the Commerce Clause jurisprudence. The Commerce Clause is one of the several provisions of the Constitution that limit the powers of the states and of the federal government in regulating commerce. The Commerce Clause has two primary aspects: the prohibitions on the states and the prohibitions on the federal government. This is not a very difficult question. It is also an easy point to distinguish. For example, a state law that taxes the sale of goods that are part of interstate commerce, and a state law that prohibits all gambling in privately owned casinos, are two different types of laws. The former is an incidental burden on interstate commerce, and the latter is a direct regulation of commerce. A good student should be able to analyze the facts and know whether the statute at issue constitutes a direct regulation of commerce. The best answer is C.

Question:
A small town in the Northeast developed the biggest ice sculpture in the world due to a massive snow, a deep freeze, and viral coverage on the social media. Hundreds of tourists poured into the area to work on the large block of ice. They made a gigantic ice palace for a variety of Disney princesses. To handle the needs of a great number of tourists, food vendors came from all over and set up their carts. To solve the problem of congestion, safety, and insufficient security, the town passed an ordinance restricting all street vendors to a specified parking lot area. The food vendors and others were losing money under the regulation. Would a commerce clause challenge to the parking lot requirement be successful by the food stand owners?

Choices:
A. No, because there is a legitimate state or local interest here which is promoted by an even-handed procedure to control the flow of traffic for public safety, and the impact on commerce is incidental.
B. No, because the food stands do not have a significant commerce clause claim in that they are still able to sell food, and what they do does not affect interstate commerce.
C. Yes, because the state is interfering with the food cart owners' legitimate business operations, which impact heavily on interstate commerce.
D. Yes, because the local interest is favored in a discriminatory manner against all of the food cart owners from other states.
response:
E. None of the above.

Analysis:
When evaluating a commerce clause challenge, the Court looks to three factors to determine whether a burden on commerce is excessive. These are: (1) does the regulation discriminate against interstate commerce; (2) is the burden on interstate commerce clearly excessive in relation to the local benefits; and (3) is there a legitimate local interest. In this case, the facts indicate that the parking lot requirement is even-handed (i.e., it does not discriminate against interstate commerce); the burden on the food cart owners is incidental to the legitimate state interest; and, there is a legitimate local interest in traffic safety.

Answer: A.

Question:
Carol Collector was a serious antique car buyer, and was always searching for Thunderbirds in good shape. She saw a newspaper ad offering a 1964 Thunderbird sports coupe for $25,000, The ad also gave a website address "to view a picture of the car," which Carol visited, and which showed a T-Bird with a perfect body and interior. Carol paid the $25,000 and signed a sales contract which specified that the Thunderbird was "used and sold as is." When Carol went to pick up the car, she learned it was a 1968 model, which was not at all rare and worth much less than the advertised 1964 model. If Carol brings suit against the seller, the likely outcome is for

Choices:
A. Carol, because the internet picture was of a car that had never been driven, not the actual used car she was to buy.
B. The seller, because the buyer was aware the Thunderbird was sold "as is."
C. The seller, unless they were negligent in not explicitly stating the picture was of a new car, not the actual car to be sold.
D. Carol, because the "as is" disclosure was not totally effective.
response:
E. The facts stated do not give the court enough to determine which party should prevail.

The best answer is C. The seller would be liable only if it could be shown they were somehow negligent in how the description of the car was made. Since they clearly indicated the car was "sold as is," buyer is out of luck. Note, this is an "as is" sale, rather than a "used car warranty" sale where the law will fill in the gaps if the seller omitted some vital information. However, since the seller is in no way deceptive (but clearly did something that is not wise), the result should be for the seller, so long as the court does not find the seller negligent in some fashion. Therefore, C is correct, and A, B, D, and E are incorrect. If the seller were being deceptive, this question would be more properly answered as D. This is why C is correct. It recognizes that this sale was "as is" but provides a way out (negligence of the seller) if Carol wants to prevail. A is incorrect because the picture was of the car that Carol was buying, but not of the same model year. B is incorrect because Carol did not have the knowledge that she would have had if the sale was not "as is." D is incorrect because there is nothing to indicate that the seller did anything wrong. The seller simply did not give Carol what she had contracted to buy, but that was the risk Carol took when she bought "as is." E is incorrect because the facts are sufficient to determine which party should prevail. There are no other facts that need to be considered. The only way that the outcome would be different would be if Carol can show that the seller was somehow negligent in describing the car. Therefore, C is the correct answer. The answer is C. Because this is the only answer that will not give a result different than the result in the facts, it is the most persuasive answer. The UCC permits a seller to disclaim warranties. The question is whether the disclaimer was effective. To determine whether the disclaimer was effective, we must consider all of the circumstances. If the seller had made the following statements, the disclaimer would likely be effective. "We will sell the car to you as is. This means that the car is sold with all faults. There are no warranties with this car." Since the seller made a representation that the car was a 1964 model when it was a 1968 model, the disclaimer was likely ineffective. However, since the seller was not deceptive when they made the representation, the outcome will likely be that the disclaimer will be upheld. The seller will likely prevail. The only exception to this result is if the seller made the representation in a way that would create an affirmative duty of care. This is a question of fact and the only answer that accounts for this possibility is C. Therefore, C is the best answer.

Answer: C.  Note:  The UCC permits a seller to disclaim warranties.  The question is whether the disclaimer was effective.  To determine whether the disclaimer was effective we must consider all of the circumstances.  If the seller made the following statements, the disclaimer would likely be effective.  "We will sell the car to you as is.  This means that the car is sold with all faults.  There are no warranties with this car."  Since the seller made a representation that the car was a 1964 model when it was a 1968 model, the disclaimer was likely ineffective.  However, since the seller was not deceptive when they made the representation, the outcome will likely be that the disclaimer will be upheld.  The seller will likely prevail.  The only exception to this result is if the seller made the representation in a way that would create an affirmative duty of care.  This is a question of fact and the only answer that accounts for this possibility is C.  Therefore, C is the best answer.  (See UCC 2-316(2); UCC 1-103.)  Note, C is the best answer because it is the only answer that would result in a verdict for the seller.  A, B, D and E would result in a verdict for Carol.  Since the seller prevailed in Colon v. Marsteller, 136 Wn.2d 851 (1993) in a similar fact situation (one in which the disclaimer was ineffective because the seller was deceptive), A is incorrect.  Since Carol signed the contract and agreed to "as is," B is incorrect.  Since Carol will prevail if the facts indicate that the seller made the representation with intent to deceive, D is incorrect.  Since the facts are sufficient to determine which party should prevail, E is incorrect.  C is the best answer.  (See UCC 2-316(2); UCC 1-103.) She saw a newspaper ad offering a 1964 Thunderbird sports coupe for $25,000, The ad also gave a website address "to view a picture of the car," which Carol visited, and which showed a T-Bird with a perfect body and interior. Carol paid the $25,000 and signed a sales contract which specified that the Thunderbird was "used and sold as is." When Carol went to pick up the car, she learned it was a 1968 model, which was not at all rare and worth much less than the advertised 1964 model. If Carol brings suit against the seller, the likely outcome is for

Choices:
A. Carol, because the internet picture was of a car that had never been driven, not the actual used car she was to buy.
B. The seller, because the buyer was aware the Thunderbird was sold "as is."
C. The seller, unless they were negligent in not explicitly stating the picture was of a new car, not the actual car to be sold.
D. Carol, because the "as is" disclosure was not totally effective.

Correct answer: D

Question:
A university student, a citizen of State A, believes that her university violated federal law when it eliminated funding for the women's varsity volleyball team. She has sued the university, a nonprofit corporation located and incorporated in State B, and the university's athletic director, a citizen of State B, in federal court in State B. What is the best method of serving the defendants?

Choices:
A. Service as required by State B's rules of civil procedure.
B. Service by a process server's leaving copies of the summons and complaint with copies of the summons and complaint with secretaries in the respective offices of the athletic director and the university president.
C. Service by emailing copies of the summons and complaint to the athletic director and the university president.
D. Service by the student herself on the athletic director and the university president.
response:
E. Service on the athletic director and the university president by certified mail return receipt requested.

Choice A is correct because it follows the statute by following State B's rules of civil procedure. In order to serve defendants properly, the procedure under federal law must be followed, which means that the method of service must be found in the state's rules of civil procedure in which the lawsuit was filed.

Question:
A debtor owed a creditor $750 on an old debt. On July 1, the debt was barred by the statute of limitations. On August 1, the debtor ran into the creditor at a party and overheard him telling mutual friends that the debtor "is a deadbeat who weiches on his debts. " Feeling pangs of guilt, the debtor approached the creditor and orally agreed to pay him the $750 debt on September 1. The debtor refused to pay the creditor the $750 as promised on September 1St. If the creditor sues the debtor to recover the $750 debt, which would provide the strongest grounds that the debtor's oral promise was unenforceable?

Choices:
A. It was not supported by new consideration.
B. It was violative of the statute of frauds.
C. The debt was already barred by the statute of limitations.
D. There was no mutuality of obligation.
response:
Answer: C. Choices A and B are incorrect because they do not apply in this situation. Choice D is incorrect because the mutuality of obligation rule is not applicable to promises to perform pre-existing duties, such as a debtor's obligation to pay a debt.

Explanation:
A is incorrect because the promise to pay an existing debt is supported by "past consideration." B is incorrect because the statute of frauds applies only to promises that do not satisfy its requirements, and there is no issue regarding these requirements in this fact pattern. D is incorrect because the mutuality of obligation rule is not applicable to promises to perform pre-existing duties, such as a debtor's obligation to pay a debt. Since the statute of limitations precluded recovery by the creditor when it arose, the debtor's promise to pay did not create any obligation on the creditor's part to accept the payment. Therefore, choice C provides the strongest grounds for the debtor's argument that the oral promise to pay was unenforceable. Therefore, answer C. is correct. (Krellwitz)Answer: C.

Question:
Because of a sudden and unanticipated severe shortage of heating fuel, the President has ordered all offices of federal executive agencies to be open only four days per week. The President's order allows an exception to the extent that emergency circumstances require different hours of operation (as in the case of federal hospitals). When Congress enacted the appropriations statute for operating all federal executive agencies, its members assumed that the offices of those agencies would be open five days per week, but Congress did not include such a requirement in its appropriations statute or in any other statute. Is the President's order constitutional?

Choices:
A. No, because the heads of the various executive agencies have final responsibility for the operation of those agencies' offices.
B. No, because when they passed the statute appropriating monies for the operation of executive agencies, members of Congress assumed that those agencies' offices would be open five days per week.
C. Yes, because the Constitution vests the President with plenary authority to direct the administration of all federal agencies in any manner the President deems expedient.
D. Yes, because the order relates to the management of the executive branch and is not prohibited by any statute.
response:
Answer: D
Explanation
This problem can be solved by simply applying the correct constitutional principles. As explained in the text, the President has constitutional authority as Commander in Chief and as the head of the executive branch to direct the administration of all federal agencies in any manner the President deems expedient (Article II, Section 2). Thus, the President's order is constitutional, even if Congress, when appropriating funds for the operation of the various agencies, may have assumed that the offices would be open five days per week. Answer B is therefore incorrect. There is no statute that prohibits the President from ordering that federal agency offices be open only four days per week, so A is incorrect. The correct answer is D. Note that C is an incorrect statement of the relevant constitutional provision. The Constitution grants the President authority to direct the administration of all federal agencies, but it is not phrased as a "plenary" authority.
